head.title: Electron momentum distribution of a single mobile hole in the t-J model

article.h1: Electron momentum distribution of a single mobile hole in the tğ‘¡italic-tt-Jğ½italic-JJ model

span.span:
J. Stefan Institute, SI-1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, University of Ljubljana, SI-1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
J. Stefan Institute, SI-1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia

div.p: We investigate the electron momentum distribution function (EMDF) for the two-dimensional tğ‘¡italic-tt-Jğ½italic-JJ model. The results are based on the self-consistent Born approximation (SCBA) for the self-energy and the wave function. In the Ising limit of the model we give the results in a closed form, in the Heisenberg limit the results are obtained numerically. An anomalous momentum dependence of EMDF is found and the anomaly is in the lowest order in number of magnons expressed analitycally. We interpret the anomaly as a fingerprint of an emerging large Fermi surface coexisting with hole pockets.

The electron momentum distribution function nğ¤=âŸ¨Î¨ğ¤0|âˆ‘Ïƒcğ¤,Ïƒâ€ â¢cğ¤,Ïƒ|Î¨ğ¤0âŸ©subscriptğ‘›ğ¤quantum-operator-productsubscriptÎ¨subscriptğ¤0subscriptğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ¤ğœâ€ subscriptğ‘ğ¤ğœsubscriptÎ¨subscriptğ¤0italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:langle Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k PUNCT:, italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k PUNCT:, italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:ranglen_{\bf k}=\langle\Psi_{{\bf k}_{0}}|\sum_{\sigma}c_{{\bf k},\sigma}^{\dagger}c% _{{\bf k},\sigma}|\Psi_{{\bf k}_{0}}\rangle is the key quantity for resolving the structure of the Fermi surface in cuprates [1]. Here we study the EMDF for |Î¨ğ¤0âŸ©ketsubscriptÎ¨subscriptğ¤0VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle|\Psi_{{\bf k}_{0}}\rangle which represents a weakly doped antiferromagnet (AFM), i.e., it is the ground state (GS) wave function of a planar AFM with one hole and with the total momentum ğ¤0subscriptğ¤0bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf k}_{0}. In the present work we investigate the low-energy physics of the CuO22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} planes in cuprates within the framework of the standard tğ‘¡italic-tt-Jğ½italic-JJ model

div.p: where c~i,Ïƒâ€ superscriptsubscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğœâ€ OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-c ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i PUNCT:, italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\tilde{c}}_{i,\sigma}^{\dagger} (c~i,Ïƒsubscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğœOVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-c ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i PUNCT:, italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\tilde{c}}_{i,\sigma}) are electron creation (annihilation) operators acting in a space forbidding double occupancy on the same site. SiÎ±subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†ğ›¼ğ‘–italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS^{\alpha}_{i} are spin operators. Our approach is based on a spinless fermion Schwinger boson representation of the tğ‘¡italic-tt-Jğ½italic-JJ Hamiltonian [2] and on the SCBA for calculating the Greenâ€™s function Gğ¤â¢(Ï‰)subscriptğºğ¤ğœ”italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:)G_{\bf k}(\omega) [2, 3, 4] and the corresponding wave function |Î¨ğ¤âŸ©ketsubscriptÎ¨ğ¤VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle|\Psi_{{\bf k}}\rangle [5].

In general the expectation value nğ¤subscriptğ‘›ğ¤italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\bf k} has to be calculated numerically. The Ising limit, Î³=0ğ›¾0italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\gamma=0, is an exception. The quasi particle is dispersionless with the GS energy Ïµğ¤=Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµğ¤subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{\bf k}=\epsilon_{0}, the residue Zğ¤=Z0subscriptğ‘ğ¤subscriptğ‘0italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endZ_{\bf k}=Z_{0} and the Greenâ€™s function Gğ¤â¢(Ï‰)=G0â¢(Ï‰)subscriptğºğ¤ğœ”subscriptğº0ğœ”italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:)G_{\bf k}(\omega)=G_{0}(\omega). Therefore it is possible to express the required matrix elements in nğ¤subscriptğ‘›ğ¤italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\bf k} analytically and to perform a summation of corresponding non-crossing contributions to any order nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›italic-n ARROW:to ID:infinityn\to\infty. The result is

math.alttext: \displaystyle 1-\frac{1}{2}Z_{0}(\delta_{{\bf k}{\bf k}_{0}}+\delta_{{\bf k}{% \bf k}_{0}+{\bf Q}})+{1\over N}\delta n_{\bf k},

div.p: where P=âˆ‘m=0âˆAmâ¢Am+1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘š0subscriptğ´ğ‘šsubscriptğ´ğ‘š1italic-P RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:endP=\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\sqrt{A_{m}A_{m+1}} with A0=Z0subscriptğ´0subscriptğ‘0italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{0}=Z_{0}, Am=Am-1â¢[2â¢tâ¢G0â¢(Ïµ0-2â¢mâ¢J)]2subscriptğ´ğ‘šsubscriptğ´ğ‘š1superscriptdelimited-[]2ğ‘¡subscriptğº0subscriptitalic-Ïµ02ğ‘šğ½2italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ NUMBER:2 italic-t italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-m italic-J CLOSE:) CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endA_{m}=A_{m-1}[2tG_{0}(\epsilon_{0}-2mJ)]^{2}, âˆ‘m=0âˆAm=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘š0subscriptğ´ğ‘š1SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}A_{m}=1 [5] and Î³ğ¤=(cosâ¡kx+cosâ¡ky)/2subscriptğ›¾ğ¤subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦2italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\gamma_{\bf k}=(\cos k_{x}+\cos k_{y})/2. We note that the result Eqs.Â (2,3) exactly fulfills the sum rule âˆ‘ğ¤nğ¤=N-1subscriptğ¤subscriptğ‘›ğ¤ğ‘1SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1\sum_{\bf k}n_{\bf k}=N-1 and Î´â¢nğ¤â‰¤1ğ›¿subscriptğ‘›ğ¤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1\delta n_{\bf k}\leq 1. In Eq.Â (2) the only dependence on the GS momentum ğ¤0subscriptğ¤0bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf k}_{0} enters through the two delta functions separated with the AFM vector ğ=(Ï€,Ï€)ğğœ‹ğœ‹bold-Q RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-pi PUNCT:, italic-pi CLOSE:){\bf Q}=(\pi,\pi). The EMDF Î´â¢nğ¤ğ›¿subscriptğ‘›ğ¤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k} is determined only with two parameters, Pğ‘ƒitalic-PP and Z0subscriptğ‘0italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endZ_{0}, presented as a function of J/tğ½ğ‘¡italic-J MULOP:divide italic-tJ/t in Fig.Â 1. Note that P=1ğ‘ƒ1italic-P RELOP:equals NUMBER:1P=1 and Z0=0subscriptğ‘00italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0Z_{0}=0 for Jâ†’0â†’ğ½0italic-J ARROW:to NUMBER:0J\to 0, therefore the result simplifies, Î´â¢nğ¤=4â¢Î³ğ¤â¢(1-Î³ğ¤)ğ›¿subscriptğ‘›ğ¤4subscriptğ›¾ğ¤1subscriptğ›¾ğ¤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\delta n_{\bf k}=4\gamma_{\bf k}(1-\gamma_{\bf k}).

Now we turn to the Heisenberg model, Î³â†’1â†’ğ›¾1italic-gamma ARROW:to NUMBER:1\gamma\!\!\to\!\!1. Here the important ingredient is the gap-less magnons with linear dispersion and a more complex ground state of the planar AFM. Gğ¤â¢(Ï‰)subscriptğºğ¤ğœ”italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:)G_{\bf k}(\omega) is strongly ğ¤ğ¤bold-k{\bf k}-dependent. The GS is fourfold degenerate and the results must be averaged over the GS momenta ğ¤0=(Â±Ï€/2,Â±Ï€/2)subscriptğ¤0plus-or-minusğœ‹2plus-or-minusğœ‹2bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:){\bf k}_{0}=(\pm\pi/2,\pm\pi/2). To get more insight into the structure of Î´â¢nğ¤ğ›¿subscriptğ‘›ğ¤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}, we simplify the wave function by keeping only the one-magnon contributions. The leading order contribution to Î´â¢nğ¤ğ›¿subscriptğ‘›ğ¤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k} is then

semantics.annotation: italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:[ NUMBER:2 italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] PUNCT:,

div.p: with ğª=ğ¤-ğ¤0ğªğ¤subscriptğ¤0bold-q RELOP:equals bold-k ADDOP:minus bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf q}={\bf k}-{\bf k}_{0} [or equivalent in the Brillouin zone (BZ)], ğ¯=tâ¢(sinâ¡k0â¢x,sinâ¡k0â¢y)ğ¯ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘¦bold-v RELOP:equals italic-t OPEN:( TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){\bf v}=t(\sin k_{0x},\sin k_{0y}), Mğ¤0â¢ğªsubscriptğ‘€subscriptğ¤0ğªitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{{\bf k}_{0}{\bf q}} is the hole-magnon coupling and uğªsubscriptğ‘¢ğªitalic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endu_{\bf q} is the ususal spin wave Bogoliubov coefficient [2, 3]. The momentum dependence of the EMDF, contained in Eq.Â (4), essentially captures well the full numerical solution [6]. A surprising observation is that the EMDF exhibits in the extreme Heisenberg limit a discontinuity âˆ¼Zğ¤0â¢N1/2similar-toabsentsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ¤0superscriptğ‘12RELOP:similar-to italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim Z_{{\bf k}_{0}}N^{1/2} and Î´â¢nğ¤(1)âˆ-(1+signâ¢qx)/qxproportional-toğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ¤11signsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to ADDOP:minus OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus sign italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)}\propto-(1+{\rm sign}\,q_{x})/q_{x}. We interpret this result as an indication of an emerging large Fermi surface at discontinuities at points ğ¤0subscriptğ¤0bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf k}_{0}, not lines in the BZ.

The anomalous structure at ğ¤=(Â±Ï€/2,Â±Ï€/2)ğ¤plus-or-minusğœ‹2plus-or-minusğœ‹2bold-k RELOP:equals OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:){\bf k}=(\pm\pi/2,\pm\pi/2) is clearly seen in Fig.Â 2, where Î´â¢nğ¤(1)ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ¤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)} is shown for Zğ¤â¢t/Jâˆ¼1similar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ¤ğ‘¡ğ½1italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t MULOP:divide italic-J RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1Z_{\bf k}t/J\sim 1 and Î³â†’1â†’ğ›¾1italic-gamma ARROW:to NUMBER:1\gamma\to 1. The Greenâ€™s function is here approximated with the non-interacting expression, Gğ¤0â¢(Ï‰)â‰ˆ-1/Ï‰subscriptğºsubscriptğ¤0ğœ”1ğœ”italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-omegaG_{{\bf k}_{0}}(\omega)\approx-1/\omega. It should be noted that Î´â¢nğ¤(1)ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ¤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)} exhibits at Î³=1ğ›¾1italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\gamma=1 also a (weak) singularity (>1absent1RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1>1). However, the nğ¤subscriptğ‘›ğ¤italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\bf k} sum rule is still exactly satisfied. In Fig.Â 2 is for the purpose of presentation Î´â¢nğ¤(1)ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ¤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)} truncated to -6<Î´â¢nğ¤(1)<16ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ¤11ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 RELOP:less-than italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1-6<\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)}<1.

In the present work we considered the electron momentum distribution function for a single hole in AFM and possibly relevant to underdoped cuprates. Non-analytic properties encountered in Eq.Â (4) are an evidence of the emerging large Fermi surface at ğ¤âˆ¼(Â±Ï€/2,Â±Ï€/2)similar-toğ¤plus-or-minusğœ‹2plus-or-minusğœ‹2bold-k RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:){\bf k}\sim(\pm\pi/2,\pm\pi/2) coexisting, however, with a â€™hole pocketâ€™ type of a Fermi surface. As long-range AFM order is destroyed by doping, â€™hole-pocketâ€™ contributions should disappear while the singularity in Î´â¢nğ¤ğ›¿subscriptğ‘›ğ¤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k} could persist. We thus interpret this result as relevant for the understanding of the electronic structure found recently with ARPES experiments in uderdoped cuprates [1], where only portions of a large Fermi surface close to ğ¤âˆ¼ğ¤0similar-toğ¤subscriptğ¤0bold-k RELOP:similar-to bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf k}\sim{\bf k}_{0} were seen.

br.figcaption: Figure 2: Perturbative result Î´â¢nğ¤(1)ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ¤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)}, Eq.Â (4), for Zğ¤â¢t/Jâˆ¼1similar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ¤ğ‘¡ğ½1italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t MULOP:divide italic-J RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1Z_{\bf k}t/J\sim 1.
